So my exceedingly annoying cat brought a mouse into my bedroom last night and let it go, and it's taken up residence in a little hole in the skirting board where a radiator was removed and is refusing to come out

So.... any ideas? Do I share my bedroom with a mouse now? I tried gently tugging its tail but it just dug its claws in and I got worried about pulling off the tail! 🙀

She’s done it again! A breathless action thriller which packs an emotional punch, #ZeroDays is @ruthwarewriter’s best yet. Out 20 June (US/Canada) / 6 July (UK). Blurb below 👀 👇🏼 

***

HOW CAN YOU HIDE WHEN THE ENEMY IS EVERYWHERE?
Hired by companies to break into buildings and hack security systems, Jack and her husband Gabe are the best penetration specialists in the business. But after a routine assignment goes horribly wrong, Jack arrives home to find her husband dead. To add to her horror, the police are closing in on their only suspect – her.
On the run and out of options, Jack must decide who she can trust and how far she’s prepared to go. Can she figure out the truth, before her pursuers find her?
International bestseller Ruth Ware returns with this adrenaline-fueled thriller about a woman in a race against time to clear her name and find her husband’s killer.

***

[image description: A hand holds up an open copy of Zero Days by Ruth Ware, cover towards the camera. The cover is grey with a mint green spine and title font. There is a running woman on the front.]

Going on holiday as an author is always fraught with the hope that you'll find your new book and usually the subsequent crushing disappointment when you don't, but @newtoncomptoneditori came up trumps with copies of Una Ragazza Speciale in both Sorrento AND Venice, and bonus @a.k.benedict and @paulahawkins2010 at Venice Santa Lucia!
The It Girl is @applebooks' audiobook of the week! Thank you Apple!

Today is UK paperback publication day for The It Girl and I woke up to some completely wonderful news - The It Girl has been long-listed for the Theakstons Old Peculier Crime Novel of the Year Award. 

Readers vote on the shortlist for this award, and I would normally be shy about asking, but I have *never* been shortlisted for the Theakstons and it's a total dream of mine, so I am going to shamelessly beg: please, please please, VOTE FOR THE IT GIRL!

You can vote at the link below (you can cut and paste, or I'll post it in the link tree in my biog) and it's super easy - all you need is an email address - but you can only vote for one author - if you vote twice none of your votes will be counted

THANK YOU!! ❤️

https://harrogatetheakstoncrimeaward.com/vote/

DON'T MIND ME JUST HANGING OUT AT NUMBER ONE IN ALL KINDLE, BABY.

Sorry, it's my publication day, I'm allowed to be insufferable. 

Normal service will return soon xx

Do you love a signed and dedicated book as much as I do? 

If so, the good news is that you can pre-order Zero Days from my local independent bookshop, @citybooksbookshop, and I will sign and dedicate it with a message of your choice!

Signed copies make the best presents - they're truly personal, AND you'll be supporting a great little indy bookshop. 

You can find the link in the Linktree in my bio - just click "Zero Days - signed & dedicated" and enter the name you want in the notes at check out. 

For international shipping costs, please call or email the shop.

Yes, it's that time of year again. I'm going on the road for Zero Days!

Dates and locations below - or sign up to my newsletter for full details and booking links. The sign up link is in my bio, or cut and paste ruthware.com/book-club

VIRTUAL EVENTS

US EVENTS (times are local to the region)

Wednesday June 21 | 11:30am - Browseabout Books 

Thursday June 22 | 7pm - Curious Iguana 

Friday June 23 | 6:30pm - An Unlikely Story

Tuesday June 27 | 7pm - Midtown Scholar with @riley.sager 

Wednesday June 28 | 6:30pm - Hudson Library and Historical Society, 

Thursday June 29 | 7pm- The Novel Neighbor and St. Louis County Library 

Friday June 30 | 6:30pm - Murder by the Book

UK EVENTS

Thursday 25 May | 7pm – Waterstones Brighton with @thestigabell 

Tuesday 4 July | 6.30 – Waterstones Manchester Deansgate with @clairedouglasauthor 

Wednesday 5 July | 6.30pm - Waterstones Piccadilly. In Conversation with @realpeoplehacker (Link to come)

Thursday 6 July | 6.30 - Waterstones Liverpool. In conversation with Mark Billingham

Friday 21st July | 5pm - Harrogate Crime Festival Special Guest. In conversation with @lisajewelluk 

PHEW! That's it. I really hope I meet some of you on the road!

Today is the last chance to cast your vote for the Theakstons Crime Novel of the Year award! 

The It Girl is nominated, and it's always been my dream to be shortlisted for this award. It's decided by reader vote so I'm not too proud to beg! 

It's super quick, only needs an email address, and they don't spam you 🙏

You can cut and paste the link below, or click on the linktree in my bio and go to Vote for the It Girl tab https://harrogatetheakstoncrimeaward.com/vote/

Thank you! 🖤♥️🖤

social_posts.post_text:
Trip to the lovely @brightonwaterstones to celebrate The It Girl being long-listed for the Theakstons Old Peculier Crime Novel of the Year Award - along with some absolute titans of crime-writing. 

Voting for the shortlist is closed now and the results will be announced 15th June, but if you voted then thank you SO much. I'm crossing my fingers hard, but however it turns out, I'm so proud to have got this far!

So honoured that @AppleBooks chose Zero Days as one of the #BestBooks of June! You can check out the rest of the list at apple.co/bestbooks

Apple Books Review:

"A grieving wife races against the clock to find her husband’s killer in this pulse-pounding cyberthriller. Jacintha “Jack” Cross is a highly skilled penetration specialist who, with the help of her hacker husband, Gabe, breaks into businesses to test their security. After one job goes horribly wrong, an exhausted Jack returns home to find Gabe slouched over his computer with his throat cut—and all the evidence pointing to her. Mystery superstar Ruth Ware sinks her claws in from the brilliantly intense opening sequence. Kinetic and breathless, Zero Days follows the heartbroken Jack as she rushes through the streets of London attempting to elude police and clear her name. Each elaborate escape and stunning new reveal increases the overwhelming sense of paranoia and tension. With its fast-paced action and well-constructed mystery, this is a *perfect* summer thriller."

😍

I'm so bad at selfies I cut out half of both books but look what just arrived to join its US sister! It's my very first copy of the UK edition of Zero Days. 

The feeling of holding your book in your hands for the first time never gets old, and I can't wait to see them both out in the world xx

Very proud that @AppleBooks chose Zero Days as one of their June #MustListens! 

It's narrated by the incomparable @imogenchurchgobshite and published by @Simon.Audio
One down... ✍️

OVER THE MOON that The It Girl made it to the Theakstons Crime Novel of the Year Award shortlist!

If you voted for her, THANK YOU THANK YOU THANK YOU! 

Seriously, you have made my day / month / year. I've never been shortlisted for this award before and it's my dream.

If you want to vote for the winner, you can cut and paste this link harrogatetheakstoncrimeaward.com/vote or click on the linktree in my bio and scroll down to "Vote for The It Girl" - all you need is an email address and they don't spam you. And thank you again SO much. I know you can't see me, but I'm literally beaming!

Me and @imogenchurchgobshite 🥰

When you open the curtains and find an overnight visitor 😲

I've read Day of the Triffids so if I'm not online tomorrow please send someone round with pruning shears and a strong herbicide
TFW your book is bigger than you are!

Dream afternoon at @harrogatefestivals Theakstons crime writing festival, doing an in conversation panel with the inimitable @lisajewelluk in front of a frankly terrifyingly huge sell out crowd.

We talked books, plotting, and answered some truly excellent audience questions (do you prefer writing nice characters or unpleasant people?)

I think we could have carried on all night but we only had an hour - here we are after the event, preparing for the signing queue to descend! 🥂

Unlike everyone else I don't have a photodump of @harrogatefestivals because I never remember to take pics - so instead here are some memories:

Dream panel with @lisajewelluk in front of a packed house

Finally getting to meet @leoking8473 in the flesh!

Gossiping in corners with @laurashepherdrobinson  @sharilapena @janecaseyauthor , @erinjelly , @claremackwrites @markedwardsauthor @radiomukhers @edjamesauthor,  @queennads, @vaseemkhanwriter and so many more.

Hugging more bloggers and readers and signing more books than I can count

Dressing up as Stella Harris, guerilla street artist for the Murder Mystery Dinner (in company with @lucavestewriter @ellygriffiths17 and @richardcarmitage among others)

Raising a glass to @misterosman's new book

Celebrating our Theakstons shortlisting with Elly, @writerdougj @gillianmauthor and @fionacumminsauthor (and cheering on @m.w.craven who won!)

More gin and tonics than I care to count.

Congratulations to the whole team for smashing it out of the park yet again and a thousand hugs to all the people I saw but haven't tagged. See you there next year?!
UK crime writers today

Well, I didn't win the Theakstons Crime Novel of the Year Award, but being shortlisted was a complete dream - and I did get this very handsome engraved cup (which was extraordinarily hard to photograph, so I hope you can see the inscription).

Congratulations to @m.w.craven, a truly deserving winner for The Botanist - and to @ellygriffiths17, highly commended for the conclusion to her beloved Ruth Galloway series.

And commiserations to my fellow shortlistees, @fionacumminsauthor , @writerdougj and @gillianmauthor . I would have been proud to lose to any of you.

My secret confession is that I don't like beer and have never actually drunk more than a sip - so had I won, my plan was to reveal this on stage and commit to drinking my first ever pint, starting with my very own tankard of @theakstonbrewery Old Peculier. But since I didn't win, I didn't have to make good on that promise. Maybe another year though?!
The air is chilly, the windows are misted, and the leaves are starting to turn. Who's ready for autumn?! 🙋‍♀️

Obviously I read -and blurb - a lot of crime but I also love non crime books and I don't often get asked to blurb those, so I thought I'd do a post celebrating some of the non crimey books I've read and loved this past year! Some are not pictured because I either read them in e version, or I gave them away. 

Children of the Sun by @bethlewis.author - this is impossible to categorise in a kind of Sarah Pinborough way, but if you love novels about cults and conspiracies, you'll love this.

Wool by @hughhowey - very late to the party on this but I loved it - though I read it thinking it would be a break from crime and it turned out to be a total police procedural, just set in a dystopian underground society many years in the future.

Tomorrow and Tomorrow and Tomorrow by @gabriellezevin - not sure this needs any more recommendations but you can add mine to the list. A wonderful story of friendship, success and loss, it reminded me a bit of The Interestings by @megwolitzer only set against a tech background. Beautifully written.

Carrie Soto is Back by @tjenkinsreid - my favourite TJR so far. Carrie is a fantastic creation (and if you have no interest in tennis, neither do I so don't let that put you off)

The Lockwood and Co novels by @jonathan.stroud - I was turned onto these clever YA novels by the Netflix adaptation which is brilliant and it's a crime they've cancelled it. Ghostly fun and a lovely will-they-won't-they relationship at the heart of the series.

Yellowface by @kuangrf - I guess this is crime adjacent since June does kick the novel off by committing a crime, but really this is about how deeply dysfunctional the publishing industry is, so every author I know has gobbled it up!

The List by @yomi.adegoke - a thoughtful what-would-you-do story told from two perspectives, Michael, who has been accused of harassment on social media, and Ola, his fiancée, who has to decide how well she knows him

Here Is the Beehive by @sarahcrossanwriter - another one I'm shamefully late to as this came out a few years ago and I started it but somehow lost my copy and only refound it this summer. It's beautifully told in blank verse, very short, and heartbreaking!
My husband gave me this brooch so I can slide it up and down at social gatherings 😆😆😆
The Netherlands quick off the mark with the very FIRST translation of Zero Days ❤️ Thank you @lsamsterdam - Jack looks stunning in Dutch!
Went out for bread and accidentally bought a dress. But seriously, is that not the most gloriously autumnal pattern you've ever seen? And - POCKETS. To slip a handful of conkers in.
NDB just actual Time Magazine naming one of my books as one of the hundred best mysteries of ALL TIME alongside some of my absolute heroes.

Conkers! Not very big ones... perhaps it was a bad season for conkers or maybe the big ones are coming later.

Edited for the non 🇬🇧 - horse chestnuts! That's what we call them over here to distinguish them from the eating kind.

If you grew up before mobile phones, you threaded them with a skewer and string and played a painful game that involved getting accidentally hit a lot.

Well would you LOOK at this. Zero Days is one of @barnesandnoble's Best Mysteries of 2023. What an honour - and what lovely company. Hi @misterosman, @riley.sager, @leoking8473 and @karinslaughterauthor!

Durham Cathedral's Sanctuary Knocker. In medieval times, people who had committed "a great offence" could claim sanctuary in the cathedral if they could touch the brass knocker. They were given 37 days sanctuary (I'm not sure why 37, the law allowed up to 40) after which they had to choose between trial and exile. 

This ancient custom was carried out across England, and some cathedrals and monasteries had facilities for hundreds of fugitives to stay - but judges and the crown grew increasingly irritated by the practice and began chipping away at the ancient common laws that underpinned the right of sanctuary, first by restricting the number of sanctuaries in existence, and finally by abolishing it altogether in 1624 in a statute that formally declared the privilege of sanctuary revoked.

Today no right of sanctuary exists but you can still see the original sanctuary knocker in Durham Cathedral museum, and feel the terror and relief of the men and women slipping through the shadows of the alleys and lanes up to the cathedral close to claim its protection.
Getting ready for a little Halloween zoom event with my Indonesian publishers, Noura Books!
Happy Halloween everyone! I also had one that said "Boo!" but some little **** stole it before I could take a photo! Testament to my carving skills, I like to think.

This time of year, the view from my bedroom window is a rain dappled sea of gold and green. 

Isn't it amazing that nature just does this every year as a great gift before winter 🍂🍁🍃

Making butternut squash cupcakes and the cooked squash is cooling on the kitchen counter in a low shaft of sunshine and did you ever see anything so deliciously autumnal and cheering? No filter because honestly, it didn't need one.

For anyone wondering how my butternut squash cupcakes turned out! (Don't worry, your eyes are not deceiving you, I decided to make one big cake in the end). 

The topping is orange cream cheese icing with crystallised ginger and dried clementine slices (the clementines were a substitution for satsumas in my online grocery shop and I don't like clementines so this seemed like a good way of using them up).

I did not crystallise the ginger. I'm not that dedicated.

Butternut squash cake is delicious, a bit like a cross between carrot cake and gingerbread.

EDIT - lots of requests for the recipe! It's a modified version of this one https://www.riverford.co.uk/recipes/pumpkin-muffins but I put the mixture into a 17cm springform cake tin and cooked it longer and slower.

The frosting is just a simple cream cheese frosting - 100g butter, 100g icing sugar and 200g cream cheese beaten together with a teaspoon of orange extract.

The clementine slices took about an hour in the oven at 130 degrees C, turning every fifteen minutes. They were more for decoration to be honest - you can eat them but they're quite sharp and chewy. But they looked so pretty with the light shining through the slices like stained glass!

The lumps are crystallized stem ginger and I bought them.

✨COVER REVEAL✨ We’re thrilled to share the cover of #OnePerfectCouple by #NYTimes Bestselling author @RuthWareWriter.

#RuthWare, author of Reese’s Book Club Pick #TheLyingGame, returns with an ingenious, high-tension thriller that follows five reality TV couples trapped on a storm-swept island as a killer stalks among them.

Visit our link in bio to pre-order your copy.

Thank you @reesesbookclub for the beautiful #coverreveal! 

ICYMI - here it is - the gorgeous, moody, tropical cover for my new book ONE PERFECT COUPLE.

Tired of the daily grind, Lyla Santiago and her boyfriend Nico set out for a luxury island to film a new reality TV show with four other couples. At first everything is picture perfect - but when a tropical storm hits and the boat that is their lifeline gets swept away, things quickly go very, very wrong.

As the water runs low, and tempers rise, Lyla discovers that someone is playing this game for real. They are determined to survive at any cost - and the stakes are life and death. 

Are you a traitor... or a survivor?

You can find out more at the link in my bio - and I can't wait for you meet Lyla and discover the truth about that One Perfect Couple...

Over the moon that I can finally talk about my great secret joy over the last few months - which is that I've been invited to take the mantle of guest chair for the 2024 #TheakstonsCrime Festival, stepping into the shoes of the extraordinary @vaseemkhanwriter, and acting alongside the rest of the brilliant @harrogatefestivals planning committee.

It's been an honour and a delight to help craft a programme that reflects the strength, diversity and sheer literary inventiveness of our brilliant and bloody craft - and I can promise that Harrogate 2024 is going to be a BLAST. 

Click on my stories to hear me talking about the experience, and for a link to the festival.

See you there!
Sharing because this thing is a complete pain to make and every year I rip my hands to shreds on the holly, but I love it so and heaving it into position is the start of Christmas for me!

I'm not sure that this is what Hercule Poirot meant by his "tisanes" but every time I make this little concoction in its glass teapot I think he would probably have approved. The teapot is so clean and neat and somehow very satisfying to pour. 

@sophiehannahwriter can you comment? Have you unearthed any evidence of the tisane ingredients?

I'm going offline for Christmas lovely book friends, but thank you for filling 2023 with books and stories. Whether you celebrate or not, whether this time of year is joyful or hard (or maybe both), I hope you find some moments of peace over the holidays, and some time to curl up with a good read xxx

Author of books, wrangler of cats, eater of cakes.
New book One Perfect Couple coming this summer!
